docs.abstract: Soaring prices for Chinese contemporary art have led way for opening of hundreds of new studios, galleris and private art museums in cities like Beijing and Shanghai; Chinese auction houses that once only dealt in traditional art have now begun to put contemporary pieces on block; European galleries are also clamoring to sign unknown Chinese artists, some of whom been able to sell their works for large sums; auction and gallery frenzy has sparked debate in China about whether sales are artificially inflated to encourage speculators, rather than real collectors, to enter art market; there are also complaints that some artists are ignoring international standards by selling works directly into auction market, rather than selling first to collectors; photos (M)

headline.main: In China's New Revolution, Art Greets Capitalism

docs.snippet: Auction frenzy is gripping the art world and in response hundreds of new sellers in big cities like Beijing and Shanghai are putting contemporary experimental artworks on the block.

multimedia.caption: China’s New Cultural Revolution
multimedia.credit: More images from some emerging Chinese contemporary artists.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: More images from some emerging Chinese contemporary artists.

docs.lead_paragraph: After the peppered beef carpaccio and before the pan-fried sea bass there were raucous toasts and the clinking of wine glasses in the V.I.P. room of New Heights, a jazzy restaurant in this city's most luxurious location, overlooking the Bund. Wang Guangyi, one of China's pioneering contemporary artists, was there. So were Zhang Xiaogang, Fang Lijun, Yue Minjun, Zeng Fanzhi and 20 other well-known Chinese artists and their guests, many of whom had been flown in from Beijing to celebrate the opening of a solo exhibition of new works by Zeng Hao, another rising star in China's bubbly art scene.

docs.abstract: China's big eastern cities are scrambling to find ways to comply with law passed in 2003 ordering local governments to provide public school education for all children under their jurisdictions, including 20 million children of laborers from rural China who migrated to cities for work; these laborers have been deprived of right of their children to attend public schools, a legacy of Maoist times; many migrants have turned to private schools, many of them unlicensed and substandard; Beijing has closed down some private schools, while in Guangzhou in Guangdong Province, city has been buying out private schools and converting them into public schools; other cities are said to be extending technical assistance to migrant schools, trying to bring them up to acceptable standards; photos (M)

headline.main: In Unusual Move, Hu Demands Inquiry After Journalist's Death

docs.snippet: China’s president has ordered a speedy investigation into the killing of a journalist who was beaten to death while investigating conditions in an illegal coal mine.
docs.lead_paragraph: In a rare response to a criminal incident, China's president, Hu Jintao, has ordered a speedy investigation into the killing of a journalist who was beaten to death recently while investigating conditions in an illegal coal mine, the semiofficial China News Service reported on Wednesday. The killing of the journalist, Lan Chengzhang, a reporter for the newspaper China Trade News, drew widespread protests from reporters in China and media advocacy groups abroad. Mr. Lan was attacked on Jan. 10, along with a colleague, when they went to interview the owner of the mine, near the northern city of Datong, in Shanxi Province. Seven people have been detained so far in the incident, and three others are still being sought, according to published reports.

docs.abstract: Reporters Without Borders accuses Pres Hu Jintao of China of seeking to bring media to heel and instigating expanding crackdown on press despite China's pledge to enhance media freedoms before 2008 Olympics in Beijing (M)

headline.main: Journalist Group Criticizes Press Freedoms Under Hu

docs.snippet: Reporters Without Borders said in its annual report on press freedoms that conditions for the news media and for journalists had deteriorated in China.
docs.lead_paragraph: A leading media watchdog group on Friday accused President Hu Jintao of China of seeking to bring the media to heel and instigating an expanding crackdown on the press despite China's pledge to enhance media freedoms before the 2008 Olympics, which are to be held in Beijing. Reporters Without Borders, based in Paris, said in its annual report on press freedoms that conditions for the news media and for journalists had deteriorated in China.

docs.abstract: Beijing Journal on archaeological sites unearthed by gargantuan construction projects for 2008 Olympics; photo; builders and archaeologists have collaborated for four years, conducting excavations and restoring three Taoist temples, including one near main Olympic stadium; situation is far different elsewhere in country, as bulldozers destroy many ancient ruins in unceasing urban development (M)

headline.main: Olympic Construction Unearths Ancient Treasure Trove

docs.snippet: Archaeologists have recovered more than 1,000 artifacts at sites being prepared for the 2008 Olympics, but elsewhere in China, they are often in a losing race against bulldozers.
docs.lead_paragraph: When this city began its gargantuan construction job for the 2008 Olympics, an early complication involved dead eunuchs. Workers had discovered a eunuch mausoleum buried under the site of the skeet shooting venue on the city's western fringe. And the eunuchs had company. Along the city's northern rim, surveyors examined the sites for the main Olympic stadiums and discovered archaeological remains tracing back 2,000 years to the Han Dynasty. In all, archaeologists excavated 700 ancient burial sites and recovered 1,538 artifacts, including porcelain urns and jade jewelry, while collecting more than 6,000 ancient coins.

docs.abstract: International consortium of physicists release first detailed design of International Linear Collider, machine 20 miles long that will slam together electrons and positrons to produce fireballs of energy recreating conditions when universe was only trillionth of a second old; machine will cost about $6.7 billion; announcement comes at Institute for High Energy Physics in Beijing, underscoring growing role and ambition of Asian nations to become major players in high-energy physics, field traditionally dominated by US and Europe (M)

headline.main: The Big Bang And the Bucks Set to Collide In Inner Space

docs.snippet: A machine 20 miles long will recreate, at a cost of about $6.7 billion, conditions when the universe was only a trillionth of a second old.
docs.lead_paragraph: The price of exploring inner space went up yesterday. At a news conference in Beijing, an international consortium of physicists released the first detailed design of what they believe will be the Next Big Thing in physics: a machine 20 miles long that will slam together electrons and their evil-twin opposites, positrons, to produce fireballs of energy recreating conditions when the universe was only a trillionth of a second old.

docs.abstract: Latest negotiations over North Korea's nuclear weapons program have begun in Beijing amid tempered optimism that breakthrough might be at hand; North Korea and US appear to be inching closer to deal that would establish schedule for North to shut down and seal its main nuclear facilities within two months, in return for shipments of fuel oil from South Korea and beginning of talks over normalization of relations with US; photo (M)

headline.main: Deal to Shut Major North Korean Nuclear Facilities Appears Closer

docs.snippet: Despite cautious words from an American envoy, North Korea appeared closer to agreeing to a deal on Friday.

byline.original: By JIM YARDLEY and DAVID E. SANGER; Jim Yardley reported from Beijing, and David E. Sanger from Washington

docs.lead_paragraph: North Korea and the United States appeared on Friday to be inching closer to a deal that would establish a schedule for the North to shut down and seal its main nuclear facilities within two months, in return for shipments of fuel oil from South Korea and the beginning of talks over normalization of relations with Washington. But the top American envoy negotiating the deal here cautioned that the two sides remained stuck on ''one or two'' small issues.

docs.abstract: Correction on Feb 8 Beijing Journal article concerns Neolithic village discovered in Zhejiang Province
docs.snippet: The Beijing Journal article on Feb. 8 about damage to archeological remains from construction misstated the age of a Neolithic village discovered in southern Zhejiang Province and misidentified the composition of an artifact found there. The village
docs.section_name: Science; Corrections; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: The Beijing Journal article on Feb. 8 about damage to archeological remains from construction misstated the age of a Neolithic village discovered in southern Zhejiang Province and misidentified the composition of an artifact found there. The village is estimated to be 7,700 to 9,000 years old, not roughly 10,000; the artifact was clay pottery, not bronze.

docs.abstract: Bangkok has emerged as role model for pollution-choked capitals in Asia, 15 years after Thailand began battle for better air quality; its air is considerably cleaner than air in Beijing, Jakarta, New Delhi and Shanghai; World Bank environment official Jitendra Shah says Thailand's battle against air pollution provides virtual how-to manual of environmental cleanup; efforts of federal government and local officials detailed; photos (M)

headline.main: Breathing Easier as the Battle for Blue Skies Pays Off

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT

docs.snippet: A decade and a half after Thailand began a battle for better air quality, this erstwhile icon of smog has emerged as a role model for pollution-choked capitals in Asia.

byline.original: By THOMAS FULLER; Patcharin Areewong and Warangkana Tempati contributed reporting

multimedia.caption: Bangkok Is Breathing Easier (iht.com)
multimedia.credit: An erstwhile icon of smog has emerged as a role model for Asias pollution-choked capitals.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: An erstwhile icon of smog has emerged as a role model for Asias pollution-choked capitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: Black smoke billowing from tailpipes into the humid, tropical air was once a Bangkok trademark. But a decade and a half after Thailand began a battle for better air quality, this erstwhile icon of smog has emerged as a role model for pollution-choked capitals in Asia, with considerably cleaner air than Beijing, Jakarta, New Delhi and Shanghai. Some buses here still belch toxic vapor. Yet the skies in Bangkok on most days are blue, thanks to the work of a small, dedicated group of people. They have pressed the case for cleaner air despite a history of weak, short-lived governments and the country's current efforts to extricate itself from the tangled results of the military coup last September.

docs.abstract: Nederlanders, one of big three Broadway theater owners, is planning to announce details of new company Nederlander New Century, which will present and market tours and live entertainment in China; company is joint venture of Nederlander Worldwide Entertainment and China-based group Beijing Time New Century Entertainment; theater companies have been rushing to tap Chinese market for Broadway shows, hoping to gain same success that has been seen in Japan; plans by other Broadway producers to bring musicals to China noted; photo (M)

headline.main: Ballyhoo Of Broadway Shuffles Off To  China

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

docs.snippet: The Nederlanders, one of the big three Broadway theater owners, plan to present and market tours and live entertainment in China.
docs.lead_paragraph: If starry-eyed young actors dream of making it big one day on Broadway, what do starry-eyed Broadway producers dream of? China, baby. Next week the Nederlanders, one of the big three Broadway theater owners, are planning to announce the details of a new company they have formed that, among other things, will present and market tours and live entertainment in China. But the entry of the Nederlanders into the Asian market is only the latest sign of how sizzling it has become.

docs.abstract: Nederlander organization unveils plans to take Broadway to China, news conference in Beijing (S)
docs.snippet: The Nederlanders unveiled their plan to take Broadway to China at a news conference on Wednesday in Beijing, and what did it look like? Pretty much like their road show business in this country. Beijing Oriental Broadway International Theater Managem

byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON; Compiled by Peter Edidin

docs.lead_paragraph: The Nederlanders unveiled their plan to take Broadway to China at a news conference on Wednesday in Beijing, and what did it look like? Pretty much like their road show business in this country. Beijing Oriental Broadway International Theater Management Company, a joint venture between the Nederlanders and a Chinese company, will manage tours of Broadway musicals, some of which will be performed in Chinese. The company will also work with theater managers on marketing and customer service and help establish a network of theaters. The first show, a touring production of ''42nd Street,'' in English, that kicks off in September, is planned for five cities. ''It's going to grow substantially from there,'' Robert Nederlander Jr., president of Nederlander Worldwide, said. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON
